docs.lead_paragraph: People with high cholesterol may lower their levels by a third with a vegetarian diet that combines ''heart healthy'' foods, including soy and soluble fiber, a study has found. Although a healthy diet is a mainstay of controlling cholesterol, people can typically reduce levels only 10 percent by changing what they eat. As a result, doctors routinely prescribe drugs called statins to lower cholesterol.

headline.main: Cutting Cholesterol With a Soy Diet

docs.lead_paragraph: People who have mild kidney failure may do better if they refrain from diets that are high in animal protein, researchers reported yesterday. Writing in Annals of Internal Medicine, scientists said it appeared that high concentrations of protein, and especially protein from nondairy sources, were associated with accelerated decline in kidney function.

headline.main: Wise Eating, to Save the Kidneys

docs.abstract: Researchers report that people who have mild kidney failure may do better if they refrain from diets that are high in protein (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Along with their academic education, students in kindergarten through 12th grade in the Metropolitan School District of Lawrence Township in Indianapolis have another field of study: character education. Each school displays a poster listing what the district has identified as the ''life skills for building character,'' including honesty, fairness and trustworthiness. Teachers look for ways to reinforce these traits each day.

headline.main: Scientists Explore the Molding of Children's Morals

docs.abstract: Increasing number of schools across America are introducing character education programs in hopes of boltering students' resolve to resist temptation to lie, cheat, bully, use drugs and behave immorally in other ways; Dr Jerome Kagan studies links between brain growth and moral capacity; photo; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The way people respond to stress appears to be in part a function of how well off they are economically, a new study says. British researchers have found that when they exposed volunteers to mentally stressful tasks, people on the lowest economic rungs needed more time than the more affluent volunteers to get their heart rates and blood pressure readings back to normal.
docs.abstract: New study finds that way people respond to stress may be function of how well off they are economically; finds that people on lowest economic rungs need more time to recover from effects of stress (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Some studies have indicated that people who take over-the-counter drugs like ibuprofen for several years are at lower risk for developing Alzheimer's disease. Now, a new report suggests why that may be the case. Writing in the March 31 issue of Neuroscience, researchers from the University of California at Los Angeles said it appeared that ibuprofen and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, including naproxen, might dissolve the brain lesions that occur in Alzheimer's.

headline.main: Closing In on Root of Alzheimer's

docs.abstract: Spread of mysterious respiratory illness to number of Asian countries and Canada leads World Health Organization to declare 'worldwide health threat'; little is known about ailment, called severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Spread of a mysterious respiratory illness to a number of Asian countries and Canada has led the World Health Organization to declare it ''a worldwide health threat'' -- but little is known about the ailment. The health organization calls the illness severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS. No one knows why it suddenly appeared or what causes it. So far, laboratory tests have told doctors only what it is not. And with the illness failing to respond to antibiotic and antiviral drugs, standard supportive nursing care and infection control measures seem the only treatment available.

headline.main: In New Outbreak, Eerie Reminders of Other Epidemics

docs.lead_paragraph: Children who are regularly exposed to secondhand cigarette smoke appear more likely to develop cavities in their baby teeth, researchers report. Writing in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association, the researchers said it was unclear how smoke might make children more susceptible, but they offered possible explanations.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a natural response. Someone close to you contracts a disease, and you brush up on it. Penny Wolfson has taken that impulse and run with it. When she learned that her son Ansel had muscular dystrophy 15 years ago, Ms. Wolfson did not just grieve. She started writing, studying, writing, researching -- delving deeply into the disease.

headline.main: Studying a Disease in Life As Well as in the Abstract

docs.abstract: Hubert B Herring reviews Penny Wolfson's Moonrise: A Family's Journey Through Muscular Dystrophy; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: During the last year, three friends have been battling colon cancer, but in only one was the disease detected before it had spread to other organs. That one is a physician in his 50's who has had frequent colonoscopies because his mother died of the disease at an early age. He, on the other hand, can look forward to a long and healthy life, thanks to early detection.

headline.main: Best Way to Fight Colon Cancer: Take the Test

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on colon cancer; notes best way to fight colorectal cancer is to be tested; photos of well-known people who had colon cancer: cartoonist Charles Schulz, Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, actress Audrey Hepburn and former Pres Ronald Reagan (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Of all the infirmities people dread in old age, dementia may be the scariest. Many people in their 90's fear declining mental faculties more than they fear death, researchers at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., have observed. If someone lives to be that old, the thinking goes, Alzheimer's disease or some other form of dementia is practically inevitable.
docs.abstract: Recent Mayo study finds that half of nonagerians studied were perfectly alert; finds that about 12 percent had significant memory problems, but were clearheaded enough to live independently and manage daily activities on their own; many people in their 90's fear declining mental faculties more than they fear death; photo (M)
